Sedimentology (2074) 61, 881-914 doi: 10.1111/sed.'t 2o7 q
Distinct styles of fluvial deposition in a Cambrian rift basin MAURICIO G. M. SANTOS*T, RENATO p. ALMEIDA*, LUCAS p. S. GODINHO*, ANDRÉ MARCONATO* and NIGEL p. MOUNTNEYT *Instituto de Geocièncias, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua do Lago 562, Cidade ILnivercitâria, CEP 05508-080, São PauÌo, SP, Brazil (E-mail: mauriciogmsantos@gmailcom) tFluvial Research Group, Earth Sciences School of Earth and Environment, [Jniversity of Leeds, Leeds, LSz 9JT, West Yorkshirc, UK
ABSTRACT
Process-based and facies models to account for the origin of pre-vegetation (i.e. pre-Silurian) preserved fluvial sedimentary architectures remain poorly defined in terms of their ability to account for the nature of the fluvial conditions required to accumulate and preserve architectural elements in the absence ofthe stabilizing influence ofvegetation. In pre-vegetation fluvial suc- cessions, the repeated reworking of bars and minor channels that resulted in the generation and preservation of broad, tabular, stacked sandstone-sheets has been previously regarded as the dominant sedimentary mechanism. This situation is closely analogous to modern-day poorly vegetated systems deve- loped in arid climatic settings. However, this study demonstrates the wide- spread presence of substantially more complex stratigraphic architectures. The Guarda Velha Formation of Southern Brazil is a >500 m-thick synrift flu- vial succession of Cambrian age that records the deposits and sedimentary architecture of three distinct fluvial successions: (i) an early rift-stage system characterized by coarse-grained channel elements indicative of a distributive pattern with flow transverse to the basin axis; and two coeval systems from the early- to climax-rift stages that represent (ii) an axially directed, trunk fluvial system characterized by large-scale amalgamated sandy braid-bar elements, and (iii) a distributive fluvial system characterized by multi-storey, sandy braided-channel elements that flowed transverse to the basin axis. Integration of facies and architectural-element analysis with regional stratigraphic basin analysis, palaeocurrent and pebble-provenance analysis demonstrates the mechanisms responsible for preserving the varied range of fluvial architectures present in this pre-vegetation, rift-basin setting. Identified major controls that influenced pre-vegetation fluvial sedimentary style include: (i) spatial and temporal variation in discharge regime; (ii) the varying sedimentological char- acteristics of distinct catchment areas; (iii) the role of tectonic basin configuration and its direct role in influencing palaeoflow direction and fluvial style, whereby both the axial and transverse fluvial systems undertook a dis- tinctive response to syn-depositional movement on basin-bounding faults. Detailed architectural analyses of these deposits reveal significant variations in geometry, with characteristics considerably more complex than that of sim- ple, laterally extensive, stacked sandstone-sheets predicted by most existing depositional models for pre-vegetation fluvial systems. These results suggest that the sheet-braided style actually encompasses a varied number of different pre-vegetation fluvial styles. Moreover, this study demonstrates that contem- poraneous axial and transverse fluvial systems with distinctive architectural expressions can be preserved in the same overall tectonic and climatic setting.
Keywords Axial fluvial systems, pre-vegetation, Camaquã Basin, Cambrian, depositional architecture, distributive fluvial systems, pre-vegetation, rift basin.

INTRODUCTION
The interpretation of fluvial successions preserved in the rock record typically relies on the analysis of depositional features that are not necessarily diagnostic of any specific deposi- tional setting and the reconstruction of fluvial system type from preserved successions is therefore typically not straightforward. The concept of a continental rock record that is dominated by the preserved deposits of distri- butive fluvial systems has gained favour in recent years based largely on studies that rely on remotely sensed imagory from modorn-day depositional systems (e.g. Hartley et al., 2O1Oa, b; Weissmann et al., 2010), although also supported by detailed studies of ancient fluvial successions (e.g. Nichols & Fisher, 2007; Fisher et al., 2008; Cain & Mountney, 2009, 2071"). Considerable discussion exists in the published literature regarding the mechanisms by which predominant fluvial styles may become prefer- entially preserved in the rock record (Sambrook Smith et ol., 2o7o; Fielding et al., 2o1,2). How- ever, to date little work has been undertaken to apply these concepts to pre-vegetation alluvial systems. This study describes the sedimentology and stratigraphic evolution of a Cambrian fluvial succession that was oriented transverse to the axis of an evolving rift basin; further, this study considers the style of interaction of this transverse system with a contemporaneously active, axially directed fluvial system. The two preserved fluvial successions have markedly different sedimentological expressions, despite both having developed under the influence of the same set of basin controls and experiencing similar climatic regimes.
Many pre-vegetation fluvial successions are characterized by preserved sedimentary expres- sions that mimic those of present-day systems developed under the influence of arid or semi- arid climatic regimes (Long, 2006). Two main depositional styles are common in pre-vegeta- tion fluvial successions: braided fluvial architec- tures with compound-bar elements and fluvial architectures dominated by bedload-sheet elements. These two contrasting sedimentary styles are commonly considered to have arisen as a consequence of fluvial system development under the influence of different climatic settings, reflecting perennial and ephemeral flow, respec- tively (e.g. Eriksson et al., ').998,2006; Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998). Existing facies models for
such pre-vegetation fluvial systems (e.g. Cotter, 1978; Long, 1978, 2OO6, 2O77; Eriksson ef a/., 1998, 2006; Sønderholm & Tirsgaard, 1998; Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998) are not necessarily effective as tools with which to account for observed palaeoenvironmental characteristics because they do not provide a generically appli- cable methodology with which to account for climatic signatures.
This study describes a >500 m-thick fluvial succession deposited in a continental rift-basin of Cambrian age in Southern Brazil, The research was conducted through the integration of high- resolution depositional facies and architectural- element analysis, in combination with pebble- provenance and palaeocurrent analysis, and supported by the erection of a regional tectono- stratigraphic framework. Specific objectives are as follows: (i) to study different architectural ele- ments and their association with various types of primary fluvial forms, including channels, bars, dunes and sheets; (ii) to investigate the relations between preserved fluvial architecture, sediment provenance and palaeogeographic location within an evolving rift basin; (iii) to examine the relative roles played by autogenic and allogenic controls; (iv) to characterize depositional styles and fluvial palaeoenvironments in a pre-vegeta- tion, synrift alluvial-plain succession; (v) to pro- pose models with which to explain how fluvial styles can be preserved for pre-vegetation sys- tems; and (vi) to provide a predictive facies model with which to better understand pre- Silurian (i.e, pre-vegetation) systems.
This work is significant for the following reasons: (i) it provides a specific case-study for the interpretation of depositional architecture from a pre-vegetation fluvial succession; (ii) it identifies how local environmental factors act to control the preserved architecture of such sys- tems; (iii) it demonstrates the style of interplay between contemporaneously active axial and transverse fluvial systems; (iv) it outlines a method by which an improved understanding of the particular characteristics of such systems can be better understood.

Gawthorpe & Leeder, 2000). The mechanism for this capture might have arisen as a consequence of ongoing subsidence leading to an increase of gradient in a direction towards the main basin depocentre, with this fluvial system constantly migrating or avulsing towards the maximum-subsidence areas (e.g. Leeder & Gawthorpe, 1,987; Peakall, 1998).
Fluvial forms record a tendency of bars to develop upwardly from lateral- to downstream- accretion, a pattern described elsewhere by Bridge (2003), and which would be expected in longitudinal sections wherever a braid-bar shows both downstream accretion and some degree of lateral expansion. Smaller-scale bed- forms, such as minor-scours, which are charac- terized by relatively widely dispersed palaeocurrent distributions, probably reflect the presence of bar-chute and bar-top channels (Bri- stow, 1993). By contrast, larger-scale forms are characterized by relatively uniform and unimo-

dal trends of palaeocurrent data. Analyses inte- grating the complete set of palaeocurrent data, together with bounding-surface data, reveal a predominantly downstream pattern of bedform migration, showing vector mean dip direction towards 158o for bounding surfaces (n: 722) and 1B7o for cross-strata (n = 183).
The combined interpretation of outcrops shows mean palaeocurrent vectors with similar trends, but a contrasting dispersion of palaeo- current directional data. For example, the presence of scour and fill structures (Fig. 11,A'), as well as the occurrence of small-scale sets of trough cross-stratification, corroborates the idea of a more complex arrangement of bar-top channels for this succession in relation to that of the panel depicted in Fig. 118. This diffe- rence may be due to variation in the preserva- tion of the upper part of the bars due to different flow regimes as a consequence of variations in fluvial discharge related to differ- ent rates of precipitation. The presence of con- cave-up fifth-order surfaces (for example, Fig. 12) suggests considerable channelization, probably induced by the confined palaeogeo- graphic setting of this system determined by the

It seems that the fluvial-fan system located close to the eastern margin of the basin (related to the Early-Rift Fluvial System described previ- ously and the Transverse Fluvial System described below) was directly eroded by the large-scale, axial fluvial system. Moreover, the transverse orientation of the mean palaeocur- rent direction relative to that of the axial fluvial system denotes a contributory character for this particular sub-system that enables it to be distinguished from the axial fluvial system, implying that the transverse river system drained into the axial trunk river. This situa- tion, together with the basinward grain-size fin- ing described by Paim (1995), suggests a basin- wide overall downslope gradient towards the western part of the basin. Provenance analysis indicates that metamorphic and granitic base- ment regions with limited areal extent lying adjacent to the eastern margin of the basin acted as source areas to these sediments, simi- lar to the previously described early-rift fluvial system; sediment source repeatedly varied through time from distal to proximal.
Accumulation and preservation of sigmoidal- stratified sets occurs under conditions transi- tional between the dune and plane-bed stability fields (Fielding, 2006). Pebbly sandstones with normally graded foresets are interpreted as con- glomeratic unit bars with angle-of-repose formed by the avalanching of particles previously sorted in superposed bedforms (McConnico & Bassett, 2OO7). Preserved mean set thickness suggests that water depth for this fluvial system was shal- lower than that of the axial fluvial system, as would be expected for a contributory system; the ability of this system to avulse coupled with its relatively unconfined setting (in comparison with that of the axial system) would also have facilitated channel widening allowing the fluvial system to occupy broader areas.
The cyclic intercalation between bodies of trough and planar cross-bedded sets of varied thickness that are commonly eroded in their upper part by sets of plane-parallel-laminated sandstone is interpreted to reflect high variation in discharge (Miall, 1984). The presence of var- ied facies associations, including mud lenses and rippled sandstone also supports the inter- pretation of a fluvial system subject to consider- able discharge variation. The local occurrence of mud flakes implies that mud deposits were dried and then eroded, and in this way such features are indicative of sub-aerial exposure soon-after succeeded by flow characterized by traction cur- rents (cf. Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998). Mud lenses, minor-scale bedforms and mudcracks are interpreted in Fig. 17. Some laterally extensive laminated sand-sheet elements characterized by planar erosional surfaces cutting a series of fluvial forms (Fig. 10G) might record floods from the axial system that occurred at a time when the distal alluvial plain of the contributory (transverse) system acted as the floodplain to the main axial system, resulting in toe-cutting ero- sion processes (cf. Leeder & Mack, 2001), or alternatively floods originating in the uplands to the east, with reworking and erosion of the un-vegetated river-banks. This type of erosion therefore could record the lateral erosion of baj- ada-forming alluvial systems by river channels directed along the main basin axis. The style of preservation of a transverse river system drain- ing into an axial trunk river system demon- strates not only the evolution of the fluvial system on the hangingwall of a half-graben but also the evolution of the early-rift system (rift- initiation stage) into a mature through-going basin (through-going-rift) with a well-developed bajada system along its eastern margin (cf. Gaw- thorpe & Leeder, 2000).

According to the methodology pro- posed by Gibling (2006), the data presented herein are indicative of medium-width channels characterized by narrow to broad sheets, demon- strating that this system was characteristically poorly confined.
Facies analysis of soft-sediment deformed strata reveals no relation between liquefaction structures and bedform type, set thickness or grain size; thus, the deformation features occur in an apparently random distribution. This sit- uation, combined with the similarity of the studied structures with laboratory features which were triggered by seismic-shaking (Owen, 1996; Moretli et al., 1999), suggests that these structures are likely to have been trig- gered by seismic activity (Santos & Almeida, 2oIo; Santos et al., 201.2). This would be expected in a tectonically active basin, particularly during the climax rift stage, during which tectonic activity would have been heightened (Prosser, 1993). For an autokinetic
(process-based) mechanism to have served as the trigger for liquidization, a direct relation between facies and architectural elements and deformation structures would be expected (Leeder, 1987), Overturned cross-stratification reveals liquefaction events that occurred simul- taneous to current shear-drag (Allen & Banks, 7972), revealing a relation between river-flow activity and liquidization, The near-rhythmic alternation between sets preserving overturned cross-stratification and non-deformed sets suggests constant flow because the coincidence of river-flow activity and seismic-events is very unlikely to have been repeatedly recorded had the fluvial system not experienced perennial flow (Santos et a1.,2072),
Interpretation of the Early- to Climax-Rift- Stage Fluvial Systems
The Guarda Velha Formation records the deve- lopment of a complex arrangement of fluvial deposits that collectively demonstrate the coeval development of an alluvial plain comprising two laterally interacting fluvial systems: an axial river characterized by a channel belt indicative of a braided fluvial system that flowed from north to south and a transverse, contributory distributive fluvial system that flowed from east to west. A large catchment area north of the basin is interpreted from the scale of the pre- served bedforms, together with palaeocurrent and pebble provenance analysis. The main dif- ference between eastern and northern sources is the presence of a belt of quartz mylonites and mylonitic granites next to the eastern basin bor- der and trending parallel to the basin. Granites and rhyolites occur in all areas surrounding the basin. Given the restricted occurrence of these mylonites to the first few kilometres to the east of the basin, the abundance of such clast types in the t¡ansverse system (always more than 25%) suggests a greater contribution of local sources than is observed in the axial system, which is richer in reworked vein quartz, Since the transverse system was contributory to the

The area of occurrence of the Guarda Velha Formation supports the interpretation of a basin-wide intra-rift fluvial plain that, accord- ing to the variation and spatial distribution of facies associations, accommodated a complex fluvial system in which the two recognized fluvial-system types were characterized by con- trasting patterns of channels and hydraulic regimes. These were due, in part, to their dif- ferent catchment areas (identified through provenance analysis - Fig. 5 - which revealed different sediment sources), their different set- tings within the evolving rift basin (rift axis versus hangingwall rift-basin margin) and their style of lateral inter-fingering. The basinal-scale development of the hangingwall fluvial and alluvial fans to the east apparently forced the axial river system to the footwall side of the basin, a situation typical of asymmetrical rifts (e.g. Leeder & Gawthorpe, 1987; Peakall, tggA; Gawthorpe & Leeder, 2000), Indeed, the depos- its of the eastern basin margin were able to develop fluvial-dominated streams, whereas the deposits of the western basin margin were fed by proximal sources, and were rapidly reworked by the major, southerly flowing axial system. This situation is similar to those described by Gawthorpe & Leeder (2000), where hangingwall-sourced alluvial fans typi- cally present larger dimensions than footwall- sourced fans. These results collectively suggest that, although both basin borders were active, the western fault represents the main syn-sedi- mentary basin border fault that gave rise to a basin asymmetry with the western part of the basin experiencing higher subsidence rates.
There exists an overall upward-decrease in grain size throughout the Guarda Velha Forma- tion, from the early-rift fluvial system with its conglomeratic bars, passing upward through the

There is clear evidence, particularly in the transverse system, to demon- strate the increased proportion of mud lenses in higher parts of the succession. This style of preservation may have arisen as a result of cli- matic controls leading to distinct temporal changes in fluvial discharge regime, or subsi- dence rates, or to a combination of both.
DISCUSSION
The study of the early-rift succession docu- ments a coarse-grained fluvial system that flo- wed transverse to the elongate basin axis towards an inferred depocentre that developed in response to progressive movement on a main basin-bounding fault. The radial pattern of this system supports its interpretation as a fluvial fan (i.e. a distributive fluvial system) that originated close to the eastern margin of the basin and flowed towards the main depocentre in the west. The succession probably records the distal (fluvial-dominated) part of one or a series of alluvial fans, which originated close to the eastern border of the evolving basin. This system is interpreted to have evolved into the younger transverse system, and the finer- grained characteristic of this younger system might indicate that the basin was widening in an orientation perpendicular to its axis (Fis. r8).
Geological mapping of depositional units of the early- to climax-rift stage confirms that the axial fluvial succession represents a major trunk river system and that the transverse/contributory system developed contemporaneously to this, as demonstrated by the lateral inter-fingering relation of these successions. The contributory system not only supplied the axial fluvial sys- tem with additional sediment supply, but also confined it to the western region of the basin. Moreover, the western margin debris-flow-domi- nated alluvial fans also forced the axial system basinward, but probably exerted a minor influ- ence compared to that of the eastern-margin fans. This situation resulted in the axial fluvial system being confined by debris-flow-dominated alluvial fans to the west and fluvial-dominated fans to the east. This relation may have been characterized by lateral erosion due to toe-cut- ting (cf, Leeder & Mack, 2001) which could be

The main sedimentological differences between these two coeval systems most probably arose as a function of the different geomorpho- logical and basin settings that they occupied, which resulted in the adoption of different drainage patterns in the same regional basin setting (Fig. 19). Discharge was apparently greater and more consistent in the main axial trunk river, as demonstrated by the preserved depositional architecture and set and coset dimensions. This is also supported by the pres- eryation of compound bars, built by successive flood events, each promoting the accretion of additional sediment in the same macroforms (Allen, 1983), Accommodation space also played an important role in controlling the preserved
sedimentary architecture: the axial system, which was located close to the main basin- bounding fault, probably experienced greater rates of accommodation creation due to higher rates of subsidence. By contrast, accumulation of the transverse system, which developed on the hangingwall and originated at the eastem basin margin, was probably limited by a relatively slow rate of generation of accommodation, meaning that the transverse fluvial system was more prob- ably to undertake progradation and to adopt a distributive form (Nichols & Fisher, 2007). Increased rates of channel avulsion due to the presence of non-stabilized banks may also explain the occurrences of mud drapes, which would be deposited after minor- channel abandonment (Tirsgaard & Øxnevad, 1998). Some of these mud deposits wete reworked, as revealed by the local presence of intraformational mud flakes, probably in response to the cutting of new channels in the immediate aftermath of avulsion events (cf. Steel & Thompson, 1983; Cain & Mountney, 2009). These results collectively indicate considerable discharge variation. The downslope gradient of this contributory river system was probably greater than that of the trunk river, given that the former flowed from one active basin border in the east across the hangingwall, which was tilting down to the west. As a consequence, dur- ing peak precipitation, this relatively high-gradi- ent area would be subject to substantial discharge variation; floods would be more easily
drained in comparison to those affecting the axial system. An aerially limited region of hydraulic catchment, as revealed by provenance analysis, may also have contributed to a higher discharge variation than that of the axial system with its regional catchment area (cf. Walling & Moorehead, 1989; Orton & Reading, 1993), lead- ing to decreased flow during drier seasons in the transverse system.
Despite the absence of vegetation cover, the studied fluvial systems were apparently able to develop long-lived, major channelized networks. The basin-wide extent of this pre-vegetation fluvial system has allowed the recognition of particularities of the depositional architecture of a Cambrian axial river that was laterally con- fined by both fault-scarp and bajada deposits; this recognition is important for the study of pre-vegetation fluvial systems. Importantly, this tectonic setting, together with the contempora- neous deposition of two distinct fluvial systems, may have induced the incision of fluvial streams into younger deposits, and systems recording

It is plausible to suggest that the laterally extensive genetic units grouped by Cotter (1978) in the term 'sheet-braided' may in fact encompass a series of different styles of pre- vegetation fluvial systems; the lack of vegetation propitiated such laterally extensive channel forms to develop a varied number of possible flu- vial styles and these were controlled by tectonic and palaeoenvironmental settings.
The paucity of mud in the systems described here probably relates to the particular charac- teristics of this basin, which was a hydrologi cally open system. The axial fluvial system continuously removed finer-grained sediments to distal areas beyond the confines of the basin, via the downstream bypass of fine- grained sediment (Winston, 7978; Eriksson et al., 2OO6), Alternatively, mud deposits may have experienced repeated deflation (Dalrymple e¿ a1., 1985). CONCLUSIONS
Three fluvial styles have been recognized in the Guarda Velha Formation (Cambrian, southern Brazil) through detailed analysis of lithofacies, depositional architecture, palaeocurrent data and pebble-provenance studies, The lowermost (oldest) recognized fluvial system is related to the initial subsidence of the area during an early stage of rift-basin development and is character- ized by conglomeratic braided channels and bars in an arrangement indicative of a distributive fluvial system. The two overlying fluvial systems

One of these systems can demonstrably be shown to be the preserved succession of a perennial major trunk river, with preserved lithofacies and archi- tectural elements indicative of braided channels and associated longitudinal bars that underwent both lateral and downstream accretion. The other system is distinguished mostly by the preservation of deposits indicative of repeated (and probably frequent) high discharge variation and is indicative of a perennial distributive flu- vial system aligned transverse to the basin axis that flowed towards and contributed to the major trunk river. Both of these fluvial systems apparently evolved coevally throughout the cli- max rift-stage and both are interpreted as peren- nial fluvial streams, despite probably experiencing considerable differences in total discharge and its variability (particularly in the transverse fluvial system). The identification of two distinct, perennial fluvial systems fed by two different source areas, with one of these sys- tems - the transverse river system - having been fed by a relatively local source area (indicated by sources located in the eastern basin margin),

Although several aspects of the behaviour and preserved architectural style of pre-vegetation fluvial deposits are known to mimic those of modern-day arid fluvial systems, the Guarda Velha Formation demonstrates that simulta- neous deposition of different facies assemblages in a pre-vegetation fluvial plain can give rise to apparently contrasting interpretations of the external controls on deposition. This may be the case where different parts of the fluvial plain are fed by distinct catchment areas and are located in different positions in relation to the basin axis, resulting in different patterns of discharge variation occurring simultaneously in the axial river system and its contributory system. Diffe- rent rates of subsidence and accommodation generation controlled by tectonic basin setting probably served as a primary control on the preservation of the different depositional archi- tectures.
The succession preserves a great variety of types of bedform elements, many nested hierarchically within channelized elements. Despite the absence of vegetation cover, the fluvial systems discussed here were able to develop long-lived, major channelized networks; this is different from many Cambrian fluvial systems interpreted in the literature as sheet- braided styles (e.g. Todd & Went, 1991; Davies et al., 2o1\), although those were preserved in different tectonic settings (cratonic basins). Other Cambrian fluvial systems in the literature, such as the Rozel Conglomerate Formation from the British Channel Islands (Went, 2005), were also able to develop channelized elements.
Apparently, to date, the Guarda Velha Forma- tion is the only example in the literature docu- menting the preservation of the inter-fingering relation of pre-vegetation axial and transverse systems. The preservation of such varied fluvial styles characterized by channel elements with high width-to-depth ratios similar to those described for 'sheet-braided' styles (e.g. Cotter, 1978; Davies et al., 2011) was probably deter- mined by the tectonic context (i.e. rift basin), demonstrating that new studies on pre-Silurian deposits can still provide valuable information for discussions regarding the form of the land- scape on the continents prior to land-plant colo- nization. These results collectively suggest that the 'sheet-braided' fluvial style encompasses a varied number of pre-vegetation fluvial styles, each with distinct preserved architectures char- acterized by channel elements which exhibit high width to depth ratios. In this way, the pres- ent authors propose that the term 'sheet-braided' should be expanded in order to contain a num- ber of different sub-groups containing distinct pre-vegetation fluvial styles.
Existing facies models for pre-vegetation fluvial systems are not necessarily effective in accounting for climate and palaeoenvironmental controls. Resolution of climate and environmen- tal signatures for these kinds of fluvial systems is not straightforward, and must consider spatial variation of depositional architecture and relation to palaeocurrent and provenance data. Pre-vegetation fluvial systems can be as complex as many present-day fluvial systems, despite the absence of vegetation cover. This work has applied implications, including the develop- ment of more sophisticated predictive deposi-

ARTICLE INFO ABSTRACT
Soft-sediment deformation (SSD) is widely described in the litemture, but there is no clear consensus regard- ing its or¡gin and significance. Existing models for SSD in fluvial sediments do not clearly demonstrate a rc- lationship between the structures, preserved facies expression. and larger-scale depos¡tional architecture. ln this study several types of SSD structures are recorded in Cambrian fluvial deposits and these occur interbedded with undeformed strata throughout the entire stratigraphic interval. The random distribut¡on of these features in relation to primary facies types and fluvial forms indicates that they have neither a direct nor indirect relationship with any depositional processes or bedform type. We propose that the relationship of SSD at the bed-set-scale to larger-scale depositional architecture, combined with tectono-stratigraphic analysis allows the determination of both short-term fluvial hydraulic conditions in ancient stream systems, such as the nature of the flow regime responsible for depositing ancient fluvial stream successions, and the long-term subsidence rates, in the form ofmean recurrence interval ofthe seismic events responsible for trig- gering the generation of SsD in tectonically active basins.

sands) are reflected in the style of deformation and in the grain fabric. Liquefaction can be triggered by many mechanisms capable of generat- ing pore-pressure build-up, including seismic shaking, wave passage, ground-water movements or impacts (Allen, 1982). ltcan also be caused by rapid deposition in combination with a high-water table (Selley, 1969; Owen, 1995: Moretti et â1., 2001).
Many authors infer the generation of SSD structures to be triggered by'allokinetic' mechanisms, where deformation occurred in response to kinetic energy contributed from outside the deposystem (Leeder, 1987), a commonly invoked trigger being seismic activity (related to episodic fault motions), normally of magnitude 5 or greater and leading to liquidization of unconsolidated sediments in tectonically active basins (Allen and Banks, 1972; Allen, 1986; Galli, 2000). Other exam- ples of SSD structures have been attributed to 'autokinetic' triggering- mechanisms, where deformation occurred in response to kinetic energy supplied from within the depositional system ([eeder, 1987), for exam- ple by cyclic loading from vortices (Selley, 1969), from flow conditions approaching the plane-bed phase, from pressure fluctuations of river-flow activity or impulsive loading from-channel bank collapse (Lowe, 1975; Røe and Hermansen,2006), from flood surges (Owen, 1987), from flash floods (Wells et al., 1993), or from frictional drag of saturated sand (Hendry and Stauffer, 1975). Both auto- and allokinetic triggering mechanisms occur in nature and careful sedimentological analysis must be undertaken to discern the most likely origin of SSD. The recognition of triggering mechanisms is best achieved through the combined analysis of facies, identiñcation of potential triggers, and consideration of other available criteria (Owen et al,, 201I ).

l. Introductlon
Ancient examples of soft-sediment deformation (SSD) formed in response to tectonic activity are widely described in the literature (Allen and Banks, 1972; Horowitz, 1982: Leeder, 1987; Obermeier, 1996; Moretti, 2000). The relationship between preserved facies expression in thick successions characterized by occurrences ofvari- ous types ofsoft-sediment-deformed structures present in preserved sedimentary successions has been the subject of numerous investiga- tions (Selley, 1969; Lowe, 1975; Allen, 1982; Owen, 1995; Moretti et al., 1999; Røe and Hermansen, 2006; Bryant and Miall, 2010: Owen and Moretti, 2011; Owen et al., 2011).
SSD structures typically develop in shallowly buried, unconsolidated, water-saturated sediments. They form when a deformation mechanism reduces sediment strength and driving forces from the depositional environment or from the sediment column induce deformation; distinct combinations of such mechanisms and forces result in varied geometry of structures (Owen, 1987). Driving forces are defined as a physical system responsible for deformation, and relate to stresses such as grav- itational body force (which may derive ftom the uneven distribution of loads), unstable density gradients, and shear forces (Owen, I 987). These forces are reflected in the geometry of deformation (Owen, 1987). Deformation mechanisms (i.e. liquefaction and/or fluidization in

No previous studies have considered the relationship ofSSD at the bed-set-scale to larger-scale depositional architecture in fluvial suc- cessions. Abundant syn-sedimentary ssD structures are present at multiple horizons in the fluvial deposits of the Guarda Velha Forma- tion (Cambrian, southern Brazil) and here we correlate their occur- rence with lithofacies in immediately overlying and underlying bed-sets, and also to larger-scale trends in depositional architecture. These relationships enable evaluation of the timing and mode of gen- eration of the deformation structures in relation to the wider deposi- tional and tectonic setting, and the hydrological regime ofthe basin in which they accumulated,
The aim ofthis paper is to investigate SSD structures and their re- lationship to facies and architectural elements in order to reconstruct palaeoenvironmental characteristics operating during the deposition of the Guarda Velha Formation. Results demonstrate that analysis of SSD can be a useful tool for inferring prevailing conditions in fluvial palaeoenvironments. A particular aim is to provide a tool for the rccognition of activity or inactivity of river flow in pre-vegetat¡on (i.e. pre-Silurian) fluviat systems, which lack modern-day analogs and for which specific techniques to account for the interplay of cli- mate and depositional sett¡ngs are not available (Long, 2006). Depo- sitional models for pre-vegetation fluvial successions are not yet sufficiently developed to an extent whereby they can be used to fully account for the origin of preserved fluvial architectures (Long, 2012). A common technique in fluvial sedimentology (Miall, 1996) is to interpret preserved deposits through process-based and facies models that have been developed in large-part from our understand- ing of present-day river systems. However, there are no modern flu- vial systems that are directly analogous to pre-vegetation fìuvial successions; the absence ofvegetation in Pre-silurian fluvial systems apparently resulted in the accumulation of sedimentary successions that in many ways resemble those of the present-day river systems developed under the influence of an arid or semi-arid climate (Long, 2006), despite such successions yielding no direct evidence for such climatic conditions.
2. Geological setting
The Camaquã Basin in southern Brazil includes >10,000 m of siliciclastic and volcanogenic deposits of 610-530 Ma (Almeida et al., 2010), The Camaquã Supergroup (Fragoso-Cesar et al., 2003) re- cords the main tectonic and sedimentation events that affected the region from the Ediacaran to the Cambrian (Fragoso-Cesar et al., 2003; Janikian et al., 2008), and is preserved in blocks bounded by high-angle brittle faults (Almeida et al., 2012). The Guariras Group (Almeida et al., 2009) was deposited during the last basin-forming extensional event, with a NW-SE-oriented minimum stress axis (Almeida et al., 2012). The group includes > 1500 m of alluvial strata, deposited in a 50 km-wide, 120 km-long tectonic depression, and is separated from the underlying basement by an angular unconformity. The Guaritas Group is equivalent to the Guaritas Allogroup of Paim (1995) and Paim et al. (2000).
The Cambrian Guarda Velha Formation (Ribeiro, 1970: Fragoso- Cesar, 1991; Almeida et a1.,2009, Fig. I ), is the basal unit of the Guaritas Group (Almeida et al., 2009) and comprises a > 500 m-thick fluvial suc- cession that accumulated from the early to climax stages of the Guaritas Rift (Fragoso-Cesar, 1991; Paim, 1995). This succession records the de- posits and sedimentary architecture of perennial fluvial systems devel- oped in a Cambrian rift basin that developed in a wet to semi-wet climatic setting, The basal part of the succession (50 to 100 m{hick, early-rift fluvial deposits) is dominated by cobble conglomerates depos- ited by the river-dominated part of a fluvial-fan, palaeocurrents of which indicate a flow direction transverse to the basin axis, in a distrib- utive pattern. Upper and thicker deposits (>400 m-thick, climax-rift fluvial deposits) are characterized by two different fluvial associations: (i) a perennial, axially-directed, channel-braided fluvial system (axial

Alluvial fan deposits from the Pedra das Torrinhas Formation record syn-sedimentary basin-margin uplift and tectonism during the deposition of the Guaritas Group (Marconato et al., 2009). These alluvial fan deposits are laterally- related and in a few places present a lateral contact relationship with the Guarda Velha Formation.
3. Deposltional architecture and facies analysls of the cuarda Velha Formation
The Guarda Velha Formation deposits are predominantly sandy to conglomeratic with abundant internal erosional surfaces, only scarce preservation of mudstone, and rare intraformational mud-chips. The suc- cession is dominated by sets with trough and planar cross-stratification, alternating with laterally-extensive sets with plane-parallel bedding. lm- bricated cobble conglomerates are restricted to the early-rift successions, whereas fine-grained deposits, including laminated siltstone and mud- stone are restricted to the uppennost, climax-rift successions, indicating an overall fining-upward grain-size trend (Fig.2). SSD structures are ob- served only in the climax-rift succession, and are more common in the transverse fluvial system.
Preserved fluvial architecture is characterized by sandy bedforms and laminated sandstone sheets, with lateral- and downstream- accretion macroforms (Miall, 1996) occurring locally (Table 1). Abandoned-channel elements are rare and those observed tend to be draped by mudstone lenses representing ponds developed in these channels. Sheetlike elements composed of overbank fines are rare but, where present, occur atop the channel macroforms, with preservation potential likely having been enhanced by channel- avulsion (Miall, 1996). Possible overbank-fine elements are 0.2 to
0.8 m thick, and contain no evidence of pedogenesis. Only rarely do these elements contain desiccation cracks. Overbank fines and abandoned channel-fills occur only in the transverse fluvial system. Fifth-order surfaces and small- and large-scale scour-and-fill struc- tures are recognized; channel macroforms are typically wider than outcrop width, but in some instances complete elements ranging from 200 to 400 m wide are exposed.

In some deformed pebbly-sandstones, pebbles have been rotated and have sunk selective- ly within the finer matrix (Fig. 5A). Fig. 2 documents liquidization events in a 520 m-long core; the frequency ofsuch events is higher in the upper part of the succession, and no regular spacing between dis- tinct events is evident.
Many types of soft-sediment folds are recognized, including eye- shaped folds (Fig. 4B), disharmonic folds (Fig. 5B), and recumbent- folded cross-stratiñcation with axial planes parallel or nearly parallel to bounding surfaces (Fig. 4A). Other types of deformation structures in- clude synclines, anticlines (Fig. 5C), dewatering pipes (Fig. 6A), and cusps (Fig. 68). Some liquefaction events affected only one set, with bounding surfaces undeformed (Figs.4A, B, 6A). In contrast, other events deformed a stacked series ofcosets (Figs. 58, C, 7). Distinct styles ofdefor- mation were observed in different bedforms. Deformation of trough cross-stratification has led to the development ofanticlines and synclines, recumbent-folds, disharmonic folds, and ruptured stratification. Horizon- tal bedding is typically modified in the form of anticlines, synclines, and clastic dykes; deformation of climbing-ripple cross-lamination typically has a massive appearance.
The thickness of individual deformed units is from 0.1 m to more than 1.5 m. Lateral continuity is commonly interrupted by erosional surfaces, where later scours cut out the deposits, although some lateÍ- ally extensive examples of deformation exceed outcrop width (>70 m). Some liquefaction features vary laterally, passing from current-shear drag deformation structures to disharmonic folds and dewatering pipes related to associated fluidization (Fig. 7). These
fluidization structures occur only locally, most commonly as sand- in-sand dykes (30 to 80 mm wide and 50 to 100 mm high), and only rarely do they cut more than one or two bed-sets.
Most ofthe SSD bed-sets are directly overlain by erosively-based sets and cosets ofnon-deformed strata (Figs.4,6). Although SSD oc- curs in all types of architectural elements, there are also examples of each architectural element with no deformational features,
5. Discussion
5.1. Depositional setting
The climax-rift palaeogeography of the Guarda Velha Formation is interpreted as a hemi-graben in which an axially-directed, perennial braided-river of large-scale, amalgamated bars flowed next to the main depositional fault to the W, and a transverse-directed, distribu- tive river system flowed from the eastern border in the direction of the axial system. The transverse river system represents rypical bajada deposits and was contributory to the axial system. The Guårda Velha Formation succession is interpreted as the product of interac- tion between two perennial, bedload-dominated, channel-braided fluvial systems, which underwent distinct variations in river-flow dis- charge, Discharge variation was higher in the transverse river-system, as recorded by the alternation between cosets of trough cross- stratification and sets of horizontal lamination (Fig. 7); nonetheless, this transverse system preserves little evidence offlow cessation dur- ing deposition. The presence ofa predominantly sandy to conglomer- atic grain-size fraction, an abundance of internal erosional surfaces, only scarce preservation of mudstone and rare intraformational mud-chips collectively indicates that the rate of sediment supply was greater than the rate of accommodation generation and that the basin therefore developed in an overfilled state (Miall, 1990).
Depositional architecture in the Guarda Velha Formation is typi- cally organized into 1 to 20 meter-thick cycles, each beginning with an erosional scour, overlain by sandy bedforms, and passing upward to laminated sand sheets (Fig.7) and rarely to overbank fines. Pre- served cycles ofthis type are typical offluvial systems that underwent marked variations in discharge, or progressive infilling of a channel due to a rapid rate of sediment aggradation, passing repeatedly be- tween conditions responsible for generation of lower- and upper- flow regime bedforms (Fielding, 2006), The amalgamation of forms resembles proximal parts of distributary fluvial systems where chan- nel avulsion is common and frequent (Nichols and Fisher, 2007), Al- though most of the channel macroforms are highly amalgamated, flow in both described fluvial systems apparently developed in wide channels; this is suggested by the presence of many fifth-order sur- faces and large-scale scour-and-fill channels. The rare occurrence of mud bodies, absence ofpreserved aeolian sets, and sparse occurrence of low-flow-regime bedsets collectively indicate a semi-perennial to perennial hydrological regime.
5.2. D eformation sfructures
SSD structures can be interpreted through comparison with simi- lar structures generated under laboratory conditions in other studies (Owen, 1996; Moretti et al., 1999). These experiments demonstrate that the geometry of deformation structures is controlled by the pri- mary structures and the driving forces, but is independent ofthe trig- gering mechanism.
Disharmonic folds are most likely generated by gravitationally un- stable density gradients, whereas synclines and anticlines are related to deformation driven by vertical shear (Owen, lg96). Deformation driven by gravitational instabilities routinely occurs after seismic shocks and liquefaction (Moretti et al., 1999). Trough cross-strata present deformation related to current-shear drag and/or dune-collapse, resulting in non-harmonic folding and water-escape structures. Planar cross-strata present recumbent fold- ing related to current-shear drag. Plane-parallel strata deform mostly in anticlines and synclines, probably as a result ofthe presence of per- meability barriers in this type of bedding. Deformed climbing-ripple cross-lamination loses lamination and presents a massive character due to the loss of lamination contrast.
5.3. Trigge ring mechanisms
The Guarda Velha Formation contains SSD-bedsets developed in a variety of primary facies types that originally accumulated in re- sponse to lower flow-regime conditions (e.g., large-scale trough cross-stratification), including subcritical flow (e.g., climbing ripple cross-lamination), and upper flow-regime conditions (e.g., primary current lineation). Undeformed sets lying immediately above de- formed sets and possessing erosive basal surfaces post-date liquefac- tion events, and show clear time-relationships between strata (Figs. 3, 4, 6A). The intercalation of overturned cross-sets and undeformed cross-stratified bedforms shows that the deformed stra- ta were near the sediment-water interface when liquefaction oc- curred (Fig. 8). Moreover, sedimentation continued shortly after deformation events and such events were separated by episodes of fluvial sedimentation presenting the same flow characteristics re- sponsible for the deposition of the deformed strata, but preserved in an undeformed state with no SSD structures (Fig. 8). These relation- ships demonstrate that there is no direct causative link between flu- vial process and SSD. Autokinetic triggering mechanisms are
process-related and, in thís way, imply a direct relation between the morphology of the deformation structure and the nature of the SSD-hosting medium and surrounding facies assemblages.
sSD occurrence in the Guarda Velha Formation is independent of host or surrounding lithofacies type or architectural-element type (e.9., channel, levee or splay), and its distribution is apparently ran- dom throughout the succession (Fig. 2). This further suggests that de- formation was not directly or exclusively linked to any specific set of depositional processes or conditions that prevailed at the time ofgen- eration. This is supported by the presence of sections with very simi- lar facies associations and very similar bed-set scale, some of which are deformed but others of which lack SSD. Significantly, this whole range of flow conditions w¡thout any direct relationship to observed SSD excludes the possibility of an autogenic triggering mechanism (Owen and Moretti, 201 I ), and an allokinetic trigger is a more plausi- ble explanation for the origin of the deformation structures.
The proximity of the studied deposits to major syn-depositional active faults only 2 to l0 km to the west supports a seismic- triggering (i.e., earthquake-induced) mechanism as the only plausible allokinetic triggering mechanism. Additional evidence to support a seismic origin for the structures includes the nearby presence of fault-scarp-derived alluvial fans and talus aprons (Almeida et al., 2009). Furthermore, fluvial deposits ofthe younger Serra do Apertado Formation of the thermal-subsidence-induced post-rift stage of the Guaritas Group, which accumulated after a cessation of seismic activ- ity (Almeida et al., 2009), present the same facies association and de- positional architecture but lacks SSD structures. Conversely, rift- climax deposits record the nature of sedimentation at the time of the maximum rate of fault-displacement (Prosser, 1993), and associ- ated heightened seismic activity. The SSD bed-sets can therefore be shown to be seismites developed in the syn-rift setting of the Guarda

Fig. 2 shows that liquefaction events occurred at a higher frequen- cy in the upper strata of the Guarda Velha Formation. The coerse- grained, basal succession may have been subjected to similar levels of seismic activity, but the lithology was not particularly prone to liq- uefaction, However, the finer-grained upper succession clearly re- cords contemporaneous seismic activity in the numerous preserved liquefaction horizons.
5.4. Palaeoenvironmental signifcance of SSD and relevance to pre- v e getation riv er sy s tems
The lack of run-off control in the pre-vegetation world may have caused short-term high discharge peaks in the drainage basin, inducing turbulent patterns and pressure fluctuations (cf. Røe and Hermansen, 2006) that may have triggered sediment deformation. However, analy- sis ofthe studied succession indicates that deformation occured in stra- ta produced by a broad range of fluvial discharge regimes, including both low-flow and high-flow stages, and SSD has no direct relationship to particular flow conditions. Moreover, water-escape features related to groundwater upwelling are rare and of small scale, suggesting that water table was constantly near or above the depositional surface. Cross-referencing between the occurrence of seismites and preserved facies reveals that most of the liquidization events occurred at times of active flow of the river system, a situation that would be extremely

Thus, SSD can be used to infer river-flow activity, determination of which is never straightforward, especially when applied to pre-vegetation fluvial sys- tems. Apparent similarity in terms of facies architecture of perennial, pre-vegetation (i.e., pre-Silurian) fluvial systems with modern ephem- eral braided-rivers may be due to the impact of high-variability dis- charge events caused by the absence of land plants that would have otherwise acted to significantly stabilize the sandy substrate, reduce channel mobility (Davies and Gibling, 2010), and subdue run-off (Schumm, 1968), thereby dampening flood magnitude and the rate of rise to peak discharge.
6. Conclusions
Analysis of SSD structures here identified as seismites in fluvial sed- imentary successions, combined with the assessment of their occur- rence in relation to primary lithofacies and depositional architecture, permits the recognition of certain palaeoenvironmental characteristics ofancient depositional systems, Seismic event recurrence can be evalu- ated from recognition of the intercalation of soft-sediment-deformed and non-deformed horizons; river-flow activity can be evaluated through the recognition of occurrences of multiple horizons presenting seism¡tes related to current-shear drag, The present data reveal an

This integration of tectono-stratigraphic data from seismite- bearing fluvial successions is a useful tool for the reconstruction of processes operating in fluvial sedimentary environments, Through the recognition of recurrent seismic activity, variations in water- table level, bedform morphology, and time relationships between dif- ferent stratal units, important environmental information can be revealed regarding fluvial depositional dynamics. This combined in- terpretation of depositional processes and penecontemporaneous
seismites, where present, can be an important methodology in the re- construction of fluvial-system-state, particularly in pre-vegetation fluvial systems, which lack modern analogs and share many sedimen- tological characteristics of modern ephemeral rivers, regardless of their actual flow regime,

Soft-sediment deformation structures in the Applecross Formation are abundant,
complex and affect intervals up to 10 m thick. Most are associated with vertical displacements of fluid and sediment. They can be classified into one of 3 styles that relate
to mode of deformation, likely trigger, and timing of deformation relative to sedimentation.
We attril-rute the 3 styles to diffelent triggers: fluid tulbulence associated with rapid
sedimentation during flood events; seismic shocks; and groundwater movements, perhaps
artesian springs at fan toes. Most of the soft-sediment deformation occurred on inactive parts of the river system where water tables remained high. The abundance
of vertically directed soft-sediment deformation structures that formed in response to groundwater movements supports alluvial-fan or bajada-like models for Applecross
Formation palaeoenvironments and allows the recognition of overbank ("floodplain")
environments in sheet-braided fluvial systems that pre-date the extensive development
of land vegetation. The scarcity of mud and absence of binding roots in a humid, pr€-
vegetation fluvial system may help to explain the abundance of soft-sediment deformation
in the Torridonian, due to rapid runoff and infiltration rates in the absence of vegetation.
These results illustrate the value of soft-sediment deformation structures as a tool in
the reconstruction of fluvial palaeoenvironments, particularly when integrated with the
study of fluvial sedimentology.

Fieldwork study has been undertaken in NE Scotland to investigate the Silurian- to-Early Carboniferous 0ld Red Sandstone in the Midland Valley, where the most complete rccord of early sedimentation from the ORS crops out, allowing access to a relatively continuous and thick succession, which is one of the most appropriate in the world with which to develop an undentanding of the interplay between early land plants and fluvial sedimentation. ìVlost previous studies of the ORS have focused on channel-fill elements (Davidson Êt Hartley, 2010), whereas few works have explored the depositional architecture of fl oodplain elements. The increasing occurrence of calcrcte horizons throughout the ORS can be linked to changes in types of vegetation cover and styles ofbiogenic weathering by lower plants and microbes (Wright et al., 1993), thus representing one of the first records of the interplay between life, climate and continental sedimentation in the rock record. The research presented here investigates how fl oodplain intervals preserved in this succession vary from the earlier Silurian part - prior to the evolution of higher land plants - to the Early Carboniferous part.
The results contribute to a better understanding of the main controls on landscape evolution during the early phases of land colonization by vegetation, a key question in my PhD

Finally, the understanding of such impact$ or their absence, can be used to better un- dentand and predict possible variations in reservoir geometry of Precambrian and Early Palaeozoic sequences.

Lower Old Red Sandstone
The Middle to Upper Silurian of the Lower Old Red Sandstone (LORS) deposits from the Stonehaven Group exposed around the town of Stonehaven record the interreìationship of fluvial sedimentation and volcanic activity. They are characterized by trough- and planar-cross stratified, fine- to coarse sandstone, cross-stratified conglomerate, rippled and laminated siltstone, andlaminated mudstone. Trough-cross stntified sandstones commonly have liquidization structures within them, including non-harmonic

folds and recumbent-folded cross- stratification; heterolithic facies associations of lami- nated fine- sandstone and siltstone commonly record ìoading structures, including pil- lows and disrupted layers. Lava flows are 0.5 to 2 m thick and overlying sediments are commonly chancterized by very-well cemented sandstone and conglomerate, with abun- dant evidence of re-working of clasts from the underlying voìcanic beds having occurred. Overbank fines are characterized by horizontaìly-extensive, tabular bodies, each up to 2 m-think; lateral-extent of these bodies is difficult to determine due to the presence of numerous, vertical faults that displace the stratignphy. Channels are characterized by sandy bedforms and laminated sandstone sheets.
The Early Devonian deposits of the Arbroath Sandstone Member (Scone Sandstone
Formation, Arbuthnott-Garvock Group) are typically chancterized by planar and trough cross-stratified sandstone and pebbly sandstone, low- angle and horizontally bedded sand- stone, rippled cross-laminated sandstone and siltstone, and ìaminated siltstone and mud- stone. Depositional architecture is mainly characterized by sandy bedforms with asso- ciated laminated sandsheets forming multi- storey channel elements; abandoned- channels are lenticular (5 to 15 m wide) and filled by up to 0.5 m-thick deposìts of silty mud- stone. Overbank fines are characterized by tabular bodies up to 2 m think and 5 to 20 m wide; these are commonly truncated laterally and upward by upper cosets from the sandy
bedforms. Calcrete nodules are present at the top of overbank deposits and abandoned channels, whereas intraformational mudstone chips and

Upper Old Red Sandstone
The Early Carboniferous deposits from the Kinnesswood Formation of the Upper Oìd Red Sandstone (UORS) are less deformed than those of the older studied succession, allowing a more thoroughly understanding of the depositionaì environments to be deter- mined. Typical lithofacies of this formation are low-angle incìined and horizontal sand- stone, trough and planar cross-stratified sandstone, intraformational conglomerate with re- worked cìasts of caìcrete concretion, laminated siltstone, and laminated mudstone. Finning-upward cycles are common and many such cycles are capped by a calcrete hard- pan with preserved rootlets at their top. Rootlets are up to 50 mm in diameter and up to I m-long; they are found in both muddy and sandy deposits, and are clearly related to the calcrete horizons; the occurrence of the latter is related to semi-arid to arid-climatic conditions (Wright tt Marriott, 2OO7).
Channel environments were characterized by sandy, bed-ìoad dominated streams, and preserved elements of such features form sequences of single-storey sandy bedforms; intraformational mud chips and sandstone clasts such as pebbìes and cobbles of mudstone are common at some leveìs within deposits of these elements. Floodplain environments were characterized by laminated fines, and small-scale lateral-accretion channels. Preliminary Discusslon Preliminary results show an increasing
incidence of occurrence of calcretes in both the numbers of instances and thickness (in this research, no exampìes in the Middle Silurian, few examples in the Middle Devonian, and prolific examples in the Early Carboniferous), from the LORS to the UORS, reflects not only an increasing biological activity (e.9. Wright et al. (1993)) activity on the continental environment throughout the geological time, reflected in the direct relationship of calcretes horizons and rootìets, but also records the establishment of semi-arid climatic settings in the region of the Midland Valley, and also an obvious increasing occurrence of rootlets (macroscopically, this research encountered examples of vegetation only in the Early Carboniferous). lndeed, there is a sudden appearance in the Carboniferous
UORS of 0.5 to 1.5 m-thick rooted horizons: this seems to be related to the appropriate environment of floodplains which were abandoned for long periods of time (as recorded by the thick calcrete horizons), allowing biological activityto develop.
Although vegetation was present in the LORS, the increasing colonization of land plants was not foììowed by an increasing occurence of mudstone in the Midland Valley, as would be expected from the probable enhanced rates of chemical weathering as a corìsequence of such coìonization. lndeed, there are moTe prcserved muddy deposits in the Middle-Silurian LORS than in the Middle Devonian LORS, and this was probably a consequence of environmental conditions, such as the interaction between fl uvial systems, nearby prcsence of volcanic activity, and climate.
The interpìay between climatic conditions and land plant colonization is recorded in the successions of the Midland Valley: Middìe-Silurian deposits show no examples of calcrete nodules, the Middle Devonian deposits show localized examples of concretions in overbank deposits as welì as re- worked clasts of calcareous mudstone clasts, and the Early Carboniferous ones

Abstracts, 28'h IAS Meeting of Sedimentology 201 l, Zaragoza, Spain f4d. Sedimentation in rilt basins
Fluvial deposits from early to climax rift stages:
The Guarda Velha Formation, Guaritas Group, Southern Brazil
M.G,M. Santosr, R,P. Almeidar, A. Marconator & L.P.S. Godinhol
l: lnstituto de Geociôncias, Universidade de São Paulo, 5ão Paulo, Brazil (mauricioguerreiro@yahoo.com)
An integrated study of depositional architecture, facies analysis, regional stratigraphic relationships, palaeocurrent and provenance data from a more than 500 m thick fluvial succession of the Guar<ja Velha Formation in the Guaritas Rift, Cambrian, Southern Brazil, reveals three different fluvial systems and sedimentation patterns from the early to climax rifting stages: an early-rift fluvial system of braided gravel bars,
and two contemporaneous fluvialsystems from the early to climax stages, represented by a perennialaxial, trunk
fluvial system, and a tributary fluvial system presenting markedly high discharge variation and channelized forms.
The lowermost fluvial system was deposited during the early-rift initiation and is characterized by coarse-grained
sandstones deposited in braided channels and imbricated, pebble to boulder, polymictic conglomerates deposited in large dimension, low angle gravel bars, Palaeocurrent data for this lowermost succession reveal a
basin-transverse system, and this observation is supported by provenance data pointing to sediment sources
from the east of the basin. After this initial stage, a more complex fluvial system was established during the early
to climax stages of the Guaritas Rift, comprising two distinct signatures of fluvial deposits that present different
depositional architecture styles, provenance, and palaeocurrent patterns, These point to a main trunk river system, running near and parallel to the extensional, sin-depositional main active fault, These deposits present
large-scale bedforms of amalgamated bars with lateral and downstream accretion, revealing a basin-axial fluvial
system with provenance from distal areas to the north of the basin, Other contemporaneous fluvial system present more varied facies, mediurn to low scale channelized bedforms, and abundant soft-sediment deformation
features. Depositional architecture is dominated mainly by sandy bedforms and larninated sand sheets, with
minor occurrence of downstream accretion, scour-fills and abandoned scours. Palaeocurrent analysis points to a
system flowing transversally to basin' axis, towards the interpreted trunk river system, revealing a tributary system with provenance from the eastern basement. This integrated study reveals different depositional styles
developed in one same fluvial plain, a situation that, without proper stratigraphic control, could potentially lead
to misinterpretations regarding the evolution of alluvial successions and their allogenic controls. Therefore, the
effect of the size and local characteristics of distinct catchment areas may be a major control in fluvial systems of

The impact of early land plants on continental sedimentation: the Old Red Sandstone in the Midland Valley (Scotland, UK)
Mauricio G. M. Santost''*, Adrian J. Hartley3, Nigel P. Mountney2 & Luca Colombera2
l lnstitute of Geosciettces, IJniversity of Sao Paulo, Brazit
2Fluviat Research Group, lJniversity of Leects, LtK
3Flttvialsysfems Research Group, L)nfuersfty of Aberdeen, IJK
* co rre s po n d i n g a u th o r : Ir a lqçlag ngrUt!_oSlq)S¡t¡jl-çA1¡
This research examines the extent to which current models are effective in accounting for the role played by early vegetation in governing the sedimentation process, Fieldwork undertaken in NE Scotland has investigated the Silurian to Early Carboniferous Old Red Sandstone in the Midland Valley. The succession comprises a near-complete record of sedimentation through the I km-thick ORS deposits, which, since it covers the main episode of land plant colonization, is one of the most appropriate successions known globally with which to develop an understanding of the interplay between early land-plant evolution and fluvial sedimentation.
Although simple plants were present in the LORS, the progressive colonization of the fluvial plain by land plants was apparently not matched by a related increase in the occurrence of mudrock in the Midland Valley, as predicted by existing models of weathering processes. lndeed, preservation of mud-prone deposits is more prevalent in the Middle-Silurian LORS than in the Middle Devonian LORS, a situation interpreted here as a conseguence of environmental conditions. The interplay between climatic conditions and land-plant colonization is recorded by other sedimentological factors: Middle-Silurian deposits do not preserve calcrete noclules, whereas Middle Devonian deposits preserve localized examples of concretions in overbank deposits, as well as re- worked clasts of calcareous mudstone; the Early Carboniferous succession (Upper ORS) records abundant examples of calcrete horizons and hardpans, and prolific occurrences of rootlets (rhizoliths and rhizocretions), recording the enhanced effects of biogenic surface stabilization by this time. Results record not only increasing biogenic control on continental sedimentation through time, but also document the establishment of a semi-arid climatic setting in the region from the Middle Devonian to the Early Carboniferous. This research is contributing to an improved understanding of the main controls on landscape evolution during the early phases of land colonization by vegetation.

Pre-vegetation fluvial styles in a Cambrian rift basin
M.G.M. Santosr2, R.P. Almeidar, L.P.S. Godinhor, A. Marconator and N.P. Mountney2
I Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, BRAZIL. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com 2 Fluvial Research Group, University of Leeds, England, UK.
1. lntroduction The mechanisms by which many different types of fluvial system undergo sedimentation and accumulation to generate a preserved stratigraphic record are now relatively well understood and a variety of process-based and facies models now exist with which to account for the origin of many preserved fl uvial sed imenta ry a rchitectures. However,
one exception to this is that of pre-vegetation (i.e. pre- Silurian) fluvi¿l successions for which uncertainty remains regarding the nature of the fluvial conditions required to accumulate and preserve architectural elements in the absence of the stabilizing infìuence of vegetation (Long, 2012). Here we present a detailed study that demonstrates the presence of highly variable pre-vegetation stratigraphic architectures. This study utilizes facies and architectural- element analysis, integrated with regional stratigraphic basin analysis, and studies of palaeocurrent and pebble provenance data to consider the mechanisms responsible for preserving the varied range of fluvial architectures present in a rift-basin setting.
2. Pre-vegetation fluvial systems ln pre-vegetation fluvial successions, the repeated re- working of bars and minor-channels commonly resulted in
the generation and preservation of broad, tabular, stacked sandstone sheets. Preserved channel elements commonly present high width-to-thickness ratios typical of resultant sheet-braided fluvial systems. This has previously been regarded as the dominant fluvial sedimentary style prior to
the Silurian (e.9. Cotter, 1978), a situation that is closely analogous to present-day, poorly-vegetated systems developed in arid or semi-arid climatic settings.
3. The Guarda Velha Formation The Guarda Velha Formation of Southern Brazil is a >500 m-
thick synrift fluvial succession of Cambrian age that records the deposits and sedimentary architecture of three distinct fluvial successions: (i) an early-rift stage system characterized by transverse and distributary coarse-grained channel elements; and two coeval systems from the early- to climax-rift stages that represent (ii) an axially-directed, trunk fluvial system characterized by large-scale amalgamated sandy braid-bar elements, and (¡ii) a transverse, distributary fluvial system characterized by multi-storey, sandy braided-channel elements. High- resolution architectural analyses of these deposits reveal significant variations in geometry, with characteristics far more complex than that of simple, laterally extensive, stacked sandstone-sheets predicted by most existing depositional models for pre-vegetation fluvial systems.
4. Controls on pre-vegetation fluvial styles Several major controls on fluvìal sedimentary style are identified in the Guarda Velha Formation and these include: (i) spatial and temporal variation in discharge regime; (ii) the varying sedimentological characteristics of distinct catchment areas; (iii) the role of tectonic basin configuration and its direct role in influencing palaeoflow direction and fluvial style, whereby both axial and transverse fluvial systems are recognized within a rift-basin setting, each of which responds to syndepositional movement on basin-bounding faults. Climatic controls are probably present, but the recognition of such controls demands utilization of modern analogues, which are not available.
5. Conclusions This study demonstrates that the preserved sedimentary expression of pre-vegetation fluvial successions can be as complex as that of post-vegetation fluvial successions, with
depositional architectural characteristics substantially more
complex than that of simple, laterally extensjve, stacked sandstone-sheets, Th¡s suggests that the sheet-braided model (i.e channels with high width-to-thickness r¿tios) may actually encompass a varied number of different fluvial
styles, not all of which have yet been fully characterized. Moreover, contemporaneous axial and transverse fluvial systems with distinct preserved fluvial architectural expressions can be preserved in the same tectonic and climatic setting.

Palaeoenvironmental significance of soft-sediment deformation in fluvial successions: the Neoproterozoic Applecross Formation, Torridon Group, UK M.G.M. Santosr'2 and G. OwenJ
ì lnstituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com r Fluvial Research Group, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, Leeds, UK. rDepartment of Geography, Swansea University, Swansea, UK. g.owen@swansea.ac.uk
1. lntroduction A distinctive feature of the Applecross Formation is the prolific occurrence of soft-sediment deformation structures that are complex in geometry and varied in scale. We present a methodology for interpreting the significance of soft- sediment deformation in fluvial successions based on criteria that relate to sedimentary facics, depositional environment, river-flow act¡vity, and position in the fluvial plain.
2. Characteristics of the Applecross Formation The Neoproterozoic Applecross Fm of the Torridon Group, NW Scotland, is a thick and relatively uniform fluvial success¡on representing the deposits of large-scale fluvial systems. The formation is characterized by medium-grained to conglomeratic sandstones with horizontal bedding and trough and planar cross-bcdding organized in 0.3 to 2.0 m- scale sets and cosets, The depositional architecture is characterized by laterally-extensive sandbodies of mainly tabular geometry. Channel forms present high width-to- thickness ratios typical of a sheet-braided style. Stratigraphic markers are rare to absent. Due to the absence of land plants covering the fluvial plain at this time, fluvial systems experienced high rates of run-off, lacked bank stabilization, and were subject to rapid rates of sedimentation; such characteristics may have played a significant role in the development and triggering of penecontemporaneous deformation.
3. Soft-sediment deformation in the Applecross Formation and its significance
Soft-sediment deform¿tion structures can be triggered by a number of different mechanisms, separated by Leeder (,l987) into allokinetic (originating outside the depos¡tional environment, such as earthquakes and impacts) and autokinetic (related to depositional processes, such as current-shear drag, rapid sedimenration, and flash-floods). ln fluvial deposits, both allokinetic (e.9. Santos et al. 2012) and autokinetic triggers (e,9. Røe and Hermensen 2006) occur.
We have defined distinct styles of soft-sediment deformation structures based on morphology, scale, lateral variability, upward termination, and position of ¿n active layer. These are a development of the assemblages defined by Owen (1995). Style 1 Usually small-scale, laterally variable srrucrures; complexity of deformation increases upwards and is truncated upwards; deformation records both lateral and vertic¿l shear. This represents localised syn- and meta- depositional deformation triqgered by flash floods and/or rapid scdiment loading, and driven by various forces such as flow-induced lateral shear, bedform collapse and water
escape. This style forms in areas of intermittently active floodplain splays. Style 2 Laterally extensive deformation dominated by lateral shear; complexity of deformation increases upwards and is truncated upwards. This represents syn-depositional deformation drive n by current shcar over a liqucfied substrate, most likely triggered by seismic activity, although flash floods and/or rapid sediment loading are also possihle triggers. This style forms in active river tracts or previously deposited, saturated floodplain splays. Style 3 Localised and isolated deformation, commonly very large scale, dominated by vertical shear that deforms and disrupts adjacent strata, Th¡s represents post-depos¡tional deformation related to fluidization originating in the subsurface and triggered by groundwater fluctuations and/or seismic shaking. This style forms in ¿reas of abandoned river tracts.
4. Conclusions This analysis demonstrates the value of soft-sediment deformation structures in understanding the Precambrian fluvial environment. Different styles of soft-sediment deformation can be used as proxy indicators of different parts of this particular fluvial system, where the absence of fine- grained material induced the preserv¿tion of apparently monotonous sedimentary architectures.

Meandering rivers as facilitators for the Palaeozoic land-plant evolution
M.G.M. Santosr'/, N.P. Mountneyr and J. Peakall'
I Fluvial Research Group, School of Earth and Environment, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, UK. 2lnstituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, São Paulo, BRAZIL. mauriciogmsantos@gmail.com
1. lntroduct¡on The increasing prominence of meandering fluvial channel systems over geologic time has long been linked to land- plant colonization during the middle Palaeozoic (Schumm,
1 968; Cotter, 1 978). This has been recently reinforced by the
observed increase from the Cambri¿n to the Devonian in the percentage of published case studies describing fluvial successions exhibiting facies characteristic of meandering rivers (Davies and Gibling, 2010). Here we discuss the nature of this relationship and propose that the apparent sudden widespread occurrence on Earth of sedimentary features indicative of the accumulation of meandering river
deposits in the Late Silurian and its prominent increase throughout the Devonian was not primarily the consequence of the evolution of land plants; rather, it was primarily an effect of global environmental and tectonic conditions that prevailed during the Ordovician-Devonian.
2. Meandering rivers and land plants The role played by vegetation in progressively stabilizing river banks, encouraging single-thread channels at the expense of multi-thread, braided channels is argued to have caused major environmental impact in the continental alluvial realm from the Silurian onwards. Paradoxically, meandering rivers are also known from pre- vegetation successions, and spectacular high-sinuosity examples have recently been observed on Mars. Moreover, laboratory experiments have successfully demonstrated that mud content alone can be sufficient to induce meandering ch¿nnels.
lncreases in the occurrence of meandering river deposits in
the rock record occurred concurrently wìth the inception and evolution of land plants. However, early Palaeozoic plants had limited biomass, and were confined to lowland and riparian habitats; arborescence developed only during Middle- to Upper-Devonian (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998). Plant-root networks were able to penetrate no more than one metre-deep until the evolution of more complex land plants in the Late Devonian. The impact of land plants as agents for substrate stabilization and run-off retention was
therefore modest at best unt¡l the Upper-Devonian.
3. Tectonic and environmental conditions during the Late Palaeozoic
The Ordovician to Devonian conditions in the palaeocontinents of Baltica and Laurasia (from which the majority of study cases have been published) included: (ì) prolonged episodes of high eustatic sea level whereby significant areas of the continental shelves were at or close to sea level, leading to the development of extensive, low- gradient coastal plains traversed by major rivers; (ii) the
Caledonian assemblage of continents leading to the development of many large, internally-draining basins; and (iii) the amalgamation of continental landmasses in intertropical latitudes subject to high levels of rainfall in climatic zones that propitialed the generatìon of a significant volume of cohesive mud via increased rates of chemical weathering.
4. Conclusions This research supports the hypothesis that the above- descnbed condrtions induced large rivers to adopt meandering channel planforms, which in turn acted to encourage the proliferation of land plants by providing extensive, fertile, mud-prone floodplains, which acted as catälysts that enabled the acceleration of land-plant evolution and the¡r spread. Once land plant colonization was lnitiated, plants and meandering rivers developed a synergistic relationship, whereby plants acted as substrate-
stabilizing and soil-forming agents that resulted in a progressive increase in the incidence of meandering river environments.
